eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma appears to be normal. No hyper-echoic focal stranding, no cysts, no masses, no calcification, and no lobularity were seen. The main pancreatic duct is normal in caliber with no echogenic duct wall thickening, no strictures, no stones, and no mural nodules.

BILE DUCT: The CBD appears to be normal, measuring about 6.6 mm in diameter, with no wall thickening, dilation, stones, or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appears to be normal with no pericholecystic fluids, stones, or wall thickening.

LIVER: The visualized portions of the liver are normal with no focal lesions or suspicious findings.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appears to be normal.

PERITONEUM: No ascites or nodular deposits were seen.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared normal with no ulcers, nodularity, or abnormalities.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal with no erythema, villous blunting, or mass lesions.

eus_findings: PANCREAS: The pancreas appeared normal in general with no evidence of hyper-echoic foci, stranding, or lobularity. The main pancreatic duct was evaluated throughout and measured 1.3 mm at the head, 1.7 mm in the body, and 0.9 mm in the tail, with smooth tapering and no dilation, strictures, stones, thickening, or masses. There were no dilated branch ducts or pancreatic cysts identified.\n\nBILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring 1.4 mm in diameter with no dilation, stones, or wall thickening.

eus_findings: PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma appeared normal with no calcifications, masses, or cysts. There were no hyperechoic foci or strands and no lobularity. The main pancreatic duct was normal in caliber, measuring 2.8 mm at the head, 2 mm at the neck, 1.4 mm in the body, and 0.9 mm at the tail. There was no echogenic duct wall thickening, stones, or mural nodules.\n\nBILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring 4.2 mm in diameter, with no stones, dilations, or wall thickening.

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreas was visualized from the head to the tail. The parenchyma of the head showed nonspecific hyperechoic foci and strands. The main pancreatic duct in the head measured 2.2 mm, in the neck 1.4 mm, in the body 1.2 mm, and in the tail 0.8 mm. The ducts tapered smoothly with no dilated branch ducts identified. No masses, strictures, or stones were seen.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct measured 2.9 mm in diameter and appeared normal with no wall abnormalities or stones.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with no wall thickening, stones, or pericystic fluid.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or abnormalities.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic lymphadenopathy was seen.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Normal EUS examination of the pancreas, bile duct, gallbladder, and liver', 'Hyperechoic foci and strands in the pancreas without masses or strictures', 'Normal main pancreatic duct and common bile duct']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A single anechoic oval cyst with a septated component was seen in the body of the pancreas, measuring 9.8 mm in maximum diameter. The cyst communicated with the main pancreatic duct and was likely a branch duct IPMN. The main pancreatic duct was mildly dilated in the neck, measuring 4 mm, and 3.4 mm in the proximal body. The duct was normal in the head, mid body, distal body, and tail. No visibly obstructing lesions or pancreatic masses were seen.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct was normal, measuring 4.1 mm, with no stones or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: There was some amount of micro- sludge present in the gallbladder, but no perigallocystic fluid or wall thickening.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.
egd_findings:
ESOPHAGUS: Fine white exudates were seen in the mid and proximal esophagus, suggestive of Candida infection. Biopsies were obtained. The mucosa otherwise appeared normal with no strictures, masses, or nodularities.

STOMACH: The mucosa was variegated, consistent with chronic gastritis. Multiple biopsies were obtained from the gastric antrum and body.

DUODENUM: Erythema and edema were seen in the duodenal bulb and D2. Biopsies were obtained.
impressions: ['Branch duct IPMN in the body of the pancreas', 'Mildly dilated main pancreatic duct in the neck', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct and liver', 'Micro sludge in the gallbladder', 'Candida esophagitis', 'Chronic gastritis', 'Duodenal erythema and edema']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A focal area of heterogeneous lobularity was seen in the tail of the pancreas, measuring 17.4 mm, without a discrete mass. The appearance remains stable compared to prior imaging. The pancreas showed evidence of fatty infiltration and echogenic foci with posterior shadowing and stranding in the pancreatic parenchyma. The main pancreatic duct (MPD) was normal, measuring 2 mm at the head and 1.7 mm at the tail, with a smooth taper and no evidence of thickening, stones, mucin masses, or structures. No dilated branch ducts were seen.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal in caliber and appearance, measuring ***. There was no evidence of dilation, stones, or wall thickening.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with no evidence of wall thickening, stones, or pericholecystic fluid.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or suspicious findings.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.

ESOPHAGUS: The mucosa appeared normal with no erosions, strictures, or masses.

DUODENUM: The duodenum appeared normal with no erythema, mass lesions, or other abnormalities.

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreas appeared normal with scattered echogenic foci and strands, but without any lobularity. There were no calcifications or changes of chronic pancreatitis. The main pancreatic duct was normal in caliber and was traced from the head to the ampulla. There was no echogenic duct wall thickening, no strictures, stones, or mural nodules. No pancreatic masses or cysts were identified.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal with no dilation, stones, or abnormalities.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or suspicious findings.

LYMPH NODES: A few subcentimeter peripancreatic and perigastric lymph nodes were seen, appearing benign, heterogeneous, and predominantly hyperechoic. No celiac axis lymphadenopathy was seen.

PERITONEUM: No ascites or nodular peritoneal deposits were seen.

ESOPHAGUS: The mucosa appeared normal with no erosions, strictures, or masses.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared normal with no evidence of erosion or ulcers, nodularities, or any other abnormalities.

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The parenchyma appeared myelolobular in the pancreatic body with some amount of stranding and myofatty infiltration. A 5 mm well-defined single chambered anechoic thin-walled cyst was seen in the body of the pancreas. Another pancreatic lesion was about 4.5 mm in diameter, heterogeneous, and hyperechoic, concerning for a peripancreatic lymph node versus a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor. The main pancreatic duct measured 2.5 mm in the head, 1.4 mm in the neck, and 1 mm in the body, and tapered smoothly without any wall thickening, strictures, or stones.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct appeared normal, measuring 3.3 mm in caliber, with no dilations, stones, or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder was normal in size and shape with some amount of cholelithiasis, but no wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid.

LYMPH NODES: An 11.4 mm peripancreatic lymph node was identified.

PERITONEUM: No ascites or nodular deposits were seen.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The adrenal glands appeared normal.
egd_findings:
ESOPHAGUS: A Grade B esophagitis was present in the distal esophagus, characterized by mucosal breaks that extended about two or more mucosal folds.

STOMACH: The mucosa appeared normal, and biopsies were obtained from the gastric body and antrum to multifunctionally evaluate for H. pylori infection.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal with no evidence of inflammation, nodularity, or other abnormalities.
impressions: ['Pancreatic cyst in the body', 'Heterogeneous pancreatic lesion in the distal body, concerning for neuroendocrine tumor or lymph node', 'Cholelithiasis', 'Peripancreatic lymphadenopathy', 'Grade B esophagitis', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, peritoneum, and adrenal glands']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The parenchyma appeared homogeneous and normal with minimal fat infiltration. The main pancreatic duct was normal in caliber, measuring 2.8 mm at the head and 1.7 mm at the tail, with no echogenic duct wall thickening, strictures, stones, or mural nodules. No masses or cysts were seen in the pancreas.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or suspicious findings.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, celiac axis, or perigastric lymph nodes were visualized.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder was absent, consistent with prior cholecystectomy.

PERITONEUM: No ascites or nodular peritoneal deposits were seen.

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma appeared homogeneous with mild diffuse fatty infiltration. A cystic complex was seen in the head of the pancreas with a large cystic component measuring 29.6 mm x 19.9 mm. The cyst had no mural nodules, no gasification, and no obvious connection with the main branch of the duct. FNA was performed using a 22 gauge aspiration needle, and 60 cc of clear viscous fluid was aspirated. The main pancreatic duct appeared normal, measuring 3.0 mm in the head, 1.3 mm in the body, and 0.6 mm in the tail.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct was dilated, measuring 5.1 mm just below the hilum, with no stones, strictures, or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with some microlithiasis, but no mural thickening or pericystic fluid.

LIVER: The liver demonstrated hepatic steatosis with mild blunting of the liver edge. There were no mass lesions or intrahepatic biliary ductal dilation.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, periportal, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.
egd_findings:
ESOPHAGUS: LA grade C esophagitis with mucosal breaks involving more than 75% of the circumference was observed, but without deep alterations. A 2 cm hiatal hernia was also seen, classified as Hill Grade 3. The esophageal mucosa otherwise appeared normal with no nodularity, strictures, or masses. Biopsies were taken from the mid and proximal esophagus to rule out eosinophilic esophagitis.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared normal with no ulcers, erosions, or mass lesions. Random biopsies were taken to rule out Helicobacter pylori infections.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal with no erythema, ulcerations, or villous blunting.
impressions: ['Pancreatic head cyst with FNA performed', 'LA grade C esophagitis with hiatal hernia', 'Normal EGD examination of the stomach and duodenum', 'Hepatic steatosis with mild blunting of the liver edge', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, and lymph nodes']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreas showed lobularity and fatty infiltration, particularly in the body and tail, with some echogenic foci and stranding. The main pancreatic duct measured 2.2 mm in the neck and 1.4 mm in the body, with a smooth taper and no evidence of echogenic duct wall thickening, strictures, or stones. A 48.7 x 49.2 mm lesion was seen in the pancreatic head/uncinate process, with a primarily microcystic appearance and some macrocystic components, thin walls, and no calcification or central scar. Fine needle aspiration and needle-based confocal laser endomicroscopy (nCLE) were performed using a 19-gauge needle, with nCLE showing fine capillaries with a 'fern-like' pattern, consistent with a serous cystadenoma.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal in caliber and appearance, with no stones or strictures.

LIVER: The visualized portion of the liver appeared normal, with no focal lesions or abnormalities.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Serous cystadenoma in the pancreatic head/uncinate process, s/p FNA and nCLE', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, liver, and adrenal glands', 'Pancreatic lobularity and fatty infiltration with echogenic foci and stranding']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma appeared normal with no evidence of mass lesions, hyperechoic focal strands, or calcifications. The main pancreatic duct measured 1.4 mm in the neck, 1.1 mm in the body, and 1.1 mm in the tail, with a smooth taper and no evidence of echogenic duct wall thickening, mucin, mass lesions, strictures, or stones. Three pancreatic cysts were visualized in the neck and body. The first cyst in the neck measured 3.7 mm, was single-chambered, thin-walled, without septation or mural nodules, and had communication with the main pancreatic duct. The second cyst in the body measured 3.3 mm, was well-defined, single-chambered, thin-walled, without septation or mural nodules, and had no obvious communication with the main pancreatic duct. The third cyst in the body measured 2.7 x 6.7 mm, was well-defined, had two chambers separated by a thin septation, and no mural nodules, calcifications, or connection to the main pancreatic duct.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring 4.2 mm, with no stricture, stones, or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with no wall thickening, stones, or pericholecystic fluid.

LIVER: The visualized portions of the liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or abnormalities.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.

MEDIASTINUM: No periesophageal, subcarinal, AP window, periaortic, or subaortic lymph nodes or masses were visualized. No pleural effusion was seen.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were obtained. The mucosa in these areas appeared normal with no strictures, erosions, ulcers, or mass lesions.
impressions: ['Three pancreatic cysts in the neck and body, with characteristics suggestive of side branch IPMNs or simple cysts', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, liver, adrenal glands, and mediastinum', 'Normal limited views of the gastric and duodenal mucosa']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma showed mild atrophy near the neck and proximal body with focal fatty infiltration and lobularity, particularly in the body. The main pancreatic duct was not dilated in the body and tail but was somewhat dilated in the neck (6.3 mm) and head (5.3 mm). Multiple pancreatic cysts were identified throughout the pancreas. In the tail, cysts measured 3.3 mm, 3.1 mm, 8 mm, 20.8 mm, 9.9 mm, and 12.3 mm. A 14.3 mm cyst in the neck had a thin septum. The cyst in the head was 5.3 mm. All cysts were well-defined, single-chambered, thin-walled, without septation or mural nodules. No calcifications or communication with the main pancreatic duct were seen.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal in caliber and appearance, with no strictures or stones.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal, with no wall thickening, stones, or pericholecystic fluid.

LIVER: The visualized portions of the liver appeared normal, with no focal lesions or abnormalities.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Multiple pancreatic cysts throughout the pancreas, largest 20.8 mm in the tail', 'Mild pancreatic atrophy and fatty infiltration', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, liver, and adrenal glands']

eus_findings: PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma appeared mildly lobular with echogenic foci and strands consistent with chronic changes. A cyst was seen in the head and uncinate region, measuring 7 mm, single-chambered with thin walls, no septation, mural nodules, or calcifications. A larger multiloculated cyst with thin septations and thin walls was seen in the distal body, measuring 23.7 x 13.8 mm. No communication with the main pancreatic duct was seen. A single pass of FNA was performed on the larger cyst using a 22-gauge needle, aspirating 3 ml of fluid for molecular marker analysis. The cyst did not collapse post-aspiration, with an 8.3 mm residual portion remaining. A smaller cyst was seen in the tail, measuring 3.0 mm, thin-walled with no mural nodules, septations, or calcifications. The main pancreatic duct measured 1.3 mm in the head, 2.5 mm in the neck, and 1.3 mm in the tail, with no abnormalities, strictures, stones, or thickening.\n\nBILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring 3 mm in diameter, with no evidence of dilation, stones, or wall thickening.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared unremarkable with no ulcers, erosions, or masses.

impressions: ['Multiloculated cyst in the pancreatic body, s/p FNA', 'Smaller cysts in the pancreatic head and tail', 'Chronic pancreatic changes with echogenic foci and strands', 'Normal EUS examination of the biliary tree and pancreatic duct']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: Multiple anechoic lesions consistent with pancreatic cysts were seen. The largest cyst was in the proximal body/ neck of the pancreas, measuring 11 x 6.5 mm with a thin septation but no mural nodules or solid components. A fine needle aspiration of this cyst was performed using a 22 gauge needle with a single pass. Additional cysts were seen: one in the pancreatic head, measuring 4.8 x 6.4 mm; one in the uncinate process, measuring 8.6 x 9.6 mm; one in the pancreatic head, measuring 8.7 x 5.3 mm with a 1.5 mm septation; a cluster of sub-centimeter cysts in the body, the largest measuring 6.2 x 3.3 mm; and a 7.9 mm cyst in the tail. The main pancreatic duct was normal in diameter, measuring 1.4 mm in the head, <2 mm in the body, and 1 mm in the tail, with no duct wall thickening, strictures, stones, or mural nodules. There was some degree of lobularity and atrophy with echogenic foci and stranding.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct appeared normal, measuring 3.1 mm.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Multiple pancreatic cysts, largest 11 x 6.5 mm in the proximal body/neck, s/p FNA', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, and liver', 'Mild pancreatic atrophy with lobularity and echogenic foci']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A single lobulated anechoic cyst measuring 33x31 mm was identified at the head of the pancreas with septated components and a single 9x9 mm mural nodule within the cyst wall. Mucin was present in other compartments. The main pancreatic duct was abnormal and measured about 5 mm in the head. Fine needle aspiration was performed using a 19 gauge needle with a total of three passes. Needle-based confocal laser endomicroscopy (nCLE) using an AQ flex probe via the 19 gauge needle revealed dark papillary projections.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring about 3 mm in diameter, with no intraluminal calculi or biliary strictures.

LIVER: The visualized portions of the liver appeared normal with no abnormalities or focal issues.

SPLEEN: The visualized portion of the spleen appeared normal.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared normal with no ulcers, erosions, or mass lesions.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal with no erythema, villous blunting, or alterations.

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: Multiple pancreatic cysts were identified, consistent with multifocal branch duct IPMN. The pancreatic head cyst measured 9 mm, the body cyst measured 9 mm, and the tail cyst measured 5 mm. An elongated cluster of cysts measuring 25 mm was seen in the pancreatic head with ductal communication. No solid nodules or concerning features were identified. Fine needle aspiration was performed using a 22 gauge needle into the largest cyst in the head of the pancreas, and clear fluid was aspirated for DNA molecular marker analysis. The pancreatic parenchyma showed a few echogenic foci and stranding but was otherwise unremarkable. The main pancreatic duct measured 3 mm in the neck of the pancreas and had a normal duct wall.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct appeared normal in caliber with a thin duct wall, and no stones, strictures, or dilations were seen.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with no wall thickening, stones, or pericholecystic fluid.

LIVER: The visualized portions of the left lobe of the liver appeared normal with no suspicious findings or focal lesions.

SPLEN: The visualized portions of the spleen appeared normal.

AORTA AND CELIAC AXIS: The aorta and celiac axis appeared normal with no aneurysms or abnormal vascular structures.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.
egd_findings:
ESOPHAGUS: LA grade B esophagitis with mucosal breaks involving more than one mucosal fold but not circumferentially was observed. No nodularity, strictures, or masses were seen.

STOMACH: The gastric mucosa appeared normal with no ulcerations or mass lesions.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal with no erythema, ulcerations, or villous blunting.
impressions: ['Multifocal branch duct IPMN with multiple pancreatic cysts', 'LA grade B esophagitis', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, liver, spleen, aorta, and celiac axis']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreatic parenchyma showed scattered foci, strands, and lobularity, but no discrete masses or calcifications. The main pancreatic duct measured 1.2 mm in the head, 0.8 mm in the body, and 0.7 mm in the tail, with a smooth taper and no evidence of echogenic duct wall thickening, strictures, or stones. Two pancreatic cysts were identified: one in the body measuring 4.2 mm, well-defined, single-chambered, thin-walled, without septations, mural nodules, or calcifications, and not communicating with the main pancreatic duct; and one in the neck measuring 4.2 x 3.7 mm, well-defined, single-chambered, thin-walled, without septations, mural nodules, or calcifications, and not communicating with the main pancreatic duct.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct was normal in caliber, measuring 2.6 mm, with no strictures, stones, or abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal with no wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, or stones.

LIVER: The visualized portion of the liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or abnormalities.

LYMPH NODES: No peripancreatic, perigastric, or celiac axis lymph nodes were visualized.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Normal EUS examination of the pancreas, bile duct, gallbladder, and liver', 'Two small pancreatic cysts in the body and neck, characterized as simple cysts', 'No evidence of pancreatic cancer or chronic pancreatitis']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: The pancreas showed a few echogenic foci and stranding, but otherwise was unremarkable. The main pancreatic duct (MPD) was not dilated, measuring about 3 mm in the neck of the pancreas. There were no dilated side branches. Multiple pancreatic cysts were seen, consistent with multifocal branched intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). A 29 mm pancreatic body cyst with possible ductal communication, mucin debris, and a hyperechoic rim was seen, but no solid nodules or concerning features. Additionally, a 6 mm, 4 mm, and a 4.5 cm pancreatic tail cyst (likely a pseudocyst) were identified. Fine needle aspiration (FNA) was performed on these cysts using a 22 gauge needle.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct was normal in caliber with a thin duct wall, no dilation, stones, or strictures.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder was filled with microlithiasis, but no sludge, urofibroma, or peripapillary fluid was seen.

LIVER: The left lobe of the liver appeared normal with no focal lesions or suspicious findings.

ADRENAL GLANDS: The left adrenal gland appeared normal.

VASCULATURE: The visualized portions of the aorta and celiac axis appeared normal, with no aneurysms or abnormal vascular structures.
egd_findings:
ESOPHAGUS: The mucosa appeared normal with no erosions, nodularities, or strictures.

STOMACH: A bulge with erythema, likely from an adjacent pseudocyst, was observed. No evidence of active bleeding or mass lesions was seen.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal without any immobility blunting or alterations.
impressions: ['Multifocal branched IPMN with multiple pancreatic cysts', 'Pancreatic pseudocyst in the tail', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, liver, adrenal glands, and vasculature', 'Normal limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A 20.2 x 19.6 mm ill-defined hypoechoic solid mass was seen in the head of the pancreas. Fine needle biopsy of the mass was performed using a 22 gauge SharkCore needle with the slow pull technique. The pancreatic parenchyma otherwise appeared normal with mild fatty infiltration but no lobularity, atrophy, calcification, or irregular outer borders. There were no echogenic foci or stranding. The main pancreatic duct was not dilated and there was no evidence of echogenic duct wall, mucin, mass, lesion, thickening, or strictures. The side branches were also not dilated.

LYMPH NODES: Two peripancreatic lymph nodes measuring 14 mm and 12 mm were seen adjacent to the pancreatic head.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal.

PERITONEUM: Mild ascites was noted.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['20.2 x 19.6 mm hypoechoic mass in the head of the pancreas, s/p FNB', 'Peripancreatic lymphadenopathy', 'Normal EUS examination of the gallbladder, liver, and peritoneum']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A heterogeneous hypoechoic mass in the pancreatic body, measuring 52 mm x 40 mm, extending into the pancreatic neck, abutting the portal confluence, and encasing the splenic artery. The main pancreatic duct was dilated upstream to the mass, measuring 8 mm in diameter. The pancreas upstream to the mass appeared atrophic. Fine needle biopsy of the mass was performed using a 22-gauge short-core needle, with three passes under ultrasound guidance and color Doppler.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct was visualized within the pancreatic head, measuring 2.2 mm, and in the pancreatic body, measuring 3.1 mm, with no abnormalities.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal, with no evidence of wall thickening, stones, or pericystic fluid.

LYMPH NODES: Two peripancreatic lymph nodes were seen adjacent to the pancreatic head, measuring 14 mm and 12 mm.

LIVER: The liver showed no suspicious lesions or abnormalities.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Heterogeneous hypoechoic pancreatic mass in the body, s/p FNB x3', 'Dilated main pancreatic duct upstream to the mass', 'Atrophic pancreas upstream to the mass', 'Peripancreatic lymphadenopathy', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, and liver']

eus_findings: PANCREAS: A 16x14 mm partially circumscribed isoechoic mass with papillary projections was seen obstructing the pancreatic duct at the ampulla with upstream dilation of the duct to 9-12 mm. Fine needle biopsy of the mass at the ampulla was performed using 22 gauge short core needle. A total of 2 passes were obtained with cytotechnologist declaring adequate cellularity.  This was concerning for main duct intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN). The pancreatic duct tapers in the body to 4.4 mm and we were unable to visualize the duct in the tail. There was a small 3.5x4.6 mm cyst communicating with the pancreatic duct in the body with no concerning features, likely side branch IPMN. There was another intraductal filling defect noted in the upstream duct in the head but this was not biopsied.\n\nBILE DUCT: The common bile duct was normal and measured 4.1-4.6 mm at the ampulla. There was no involvement of the bile duct by the intraductal pancreatic mass.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Isoechoic intraductal pancreatic mass at the ampulla with marked upstream dilation of the duct, s/p FNB x2. Concern for main duct IPMN', 'Small branch duct IPMN in the body', 'Separate intraductal filling defect in the head, not biopsied', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A 34.9 x 29.1 mm pancreatic head mass was seen, which was poorly defined and heterogeneous. The main pancreatic duct traversed through the lesion and was dilated, measuring 4.3 mm. Fine needle aspiration of the mass was performed using a 22-gauge SharkCore needle, with a total of 4 passes.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct measured 5.3 mm.

LYMPH NODES: A peripancreatic lymph node was seen, measuring 13.2 mm.

eus_findings:
STOMACH: A 27x14 mm heterogeneous and hypoechoic lesion was seen originating from the muscularis propria with a small 7x7 mm anechoic area within. Fine needle biopsy of the lesion was performed using a 22 gauge SharkCore needle. A total of 3 passes were obtained with ROSE confirming adequate cellular yield.

PANCREAS: The pancreas appeared normal with no abnormalities or dilation in the main pancreatic duct.

BILE DUCT: The common bile duct appeared normal, measuring 1.4 mm in diameter, with no evidence of stones, wall thickening, or dilation.
egd_findings:
EGD was performed using an Olympus HK 190 gastroscope.

ESOPHAGUS: The mucosa appeared normal.

STOMACH: A 2 cm subepithelial lesion was seen along the greater curvature, anterior wall of the fundus. Bite-on-bite biopsies were performed.

DUODENUM: The mucosa appeared normal without evidence of a mass or other abnormalities.
impressions: ['Subepithelial gastric fundus mass, 27x14mm, s/p FNB x3, with ROSE', 'Normal EUS examination of the pancreas and bile duct']

eus_findings: PANCREAS: A hypoechoic mass lesion was found in the body of the pancreas, measuring 25.2 x 19.2 mm. Fine needle aspiration was performed using a 22-gauge SharkCore needle, with a total of 3 passes. The main pancreatic duct was dilated, measuring 1.5 mm in the head and 6.3 mm in the body.\n\n

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A 37x28 mm hypoechoic, round, and well-defined mass was seen in the uncinate process of the pancreas with peripheral vasculature, not encasing any structures. The rest of the pancreatic parenchyma was hyperechoic, suggestive of fatty infiltration. The main pancreatic duct was non-dilated, measuring 1.7 mm in the head and 0.9 mm in the tail. Fine-needle biopsy (FNB) of the mass was performed using a 22-gauge Aqua FNB needle.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct was non-dilated, measuring 3.3 mm.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder appeared normal.

LIVER: The liver appeared normal.

LYMPH NODES: No lymph nodes were seen.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Hypoechoic mass in the uncinate process of the pancreas, s/p FNB', 'Fatty infiltration of the pancreatic parenchyma', 'Normal EUS examination of the bile duct, gallbladder, liver, and lymph nodes']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: An ill-defined hypoechoic lesion measuring 6.5 mm was seen in the tail of the pancreas, adjacent to a 34.9 mm hyperechoic rounded mass (likely a splenule). The pancreatic parenchyma showed mild lobularity, fatty infiltration, and echogenic foci. The main pancreatic duct measured 3 mm at the head, 1.1 mm at the body, and <1 mm at the tail, with a smooth taper and no evidence of echogenic duct wall, mucin, mass, thickening, stricture, or stones.

SPLEEN: A 34.9 mm hyperechoic rounded mass was seen, likely representing a splenule.

LYMPH NODES: Two peripancreatic lymph nodes were seen, measuring 14 mm and 12 mm, adjacent to the pancreatic head.

LIVER: The liver was normal.

GALLBLADDER: The gallbladder was normal.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct was normal.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Hypoechoic lesion in the tail of the pancreas, unable to biopsy due to surrounding blood vessels', 'Splenule measuring 34.9 mm', 'Mild pancreatic lobularity and fatty infiltration', 'Normal main pancreatic duct and bile duct', 'Normal liver, gallbladder, and lymph nodes']

eus_findings: PANCREAS: A multi-cystic lesion with solid components was seen encasing the complete pancreatic tail and extending into the pancreatic body. The solid component measured 37.2 mm x 38.2 mm with a normal caliber appearing pancreatic duct traversing through it. Several cystic components were seen both towards the pancreatic tail and body. The cystic lesion measured approximately 47 mm x 57 mm x 81 mm. Fine needle biopsy of the solid component was performed using a 22-gauge SharkCore needle. A total of 3 passes were obtained with cytotechnologist confirming adequate cellularity.\n\nOther surrounding structures were normal.
egd_findings: EGD not performed. Limited views of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum were normal.
impressions: ['Multi-cystic pancreatic lesion with solid component, s/p FNB x3', 'Normal EUS examination of surrounding structures']

eus_findings:
PANCREAS: A hypoechoic lesion measuring 40x*** mm was seen in the tail of the pancreas, consistent with the patient's known adenocarcinoma. Multiple large collaterals were seen on the edges of the lesion and also penetrating the lesion. Fine needle aspiration was performed using a 22 gauge FNA needle.

BILE DUCT: The bile duct was normal.

LIVER: The liver was normal.

LYMPH NODES: No lymph nodes were seen.
